paragraphs.text: I survived the Bhopal gas tragedy.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: I was born in July 1984
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I was only five months old when the disaster struck my community
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I was too young to remember anything from the night of December 2, 1984
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: throughout the years, I have heard many stories from the people who were there and saw it happen
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: My sister would sometimes tell me things about that night
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: though we generally avoided bringing it up
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: as we knew that it would only hurt us to talk about it
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: After the disaster, some of our relatives, who had heard about it on the radio, came and took us to Lucknow, around 600km from Bhopal
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We stayed with them for a few months
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they started treating us badly
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: as if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we were a burden to them and their families
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it was our brother Sunil, another survivor from our family of 10 - aged 13 at the time of the disaster - who decided to bring us back to Bhopal
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Subsequently, we were sent to an orphanage in Bhopal, called The SOS Children's Village
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Sunil refused to live with us in the orphanage, and got involved with the anti-Carbide campaign
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He created an organisation called Children Against Carbide
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Most of the members of this organisation were children from the community we were from - Jay Prakash Nagar (JP Nagar), right across the road from the main Bhopal plant
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I was happy with my life at the orphanage in Bhopal
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I had almost everything: cricket bats, skates, football, good education etc
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: at the same time, I did not know anything about our parents
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In middle school, we would have parent-teacher meetings at school
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: my classmates had their parents next to them for the meeting
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I had no one next to me
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was around that time that I started asking my sister about our parents
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was then that my sister first told me about the Bhopal gas disaster and what had happened that night
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Until then, I never fully understood that I was growing up in an orphanage and didn't really know the meaning of the word "orphanage"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: My sister Mamta told me that there were four brothers and four sisters in our family
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Our father was a carpenter
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I was the youngest in the family
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We lost three sisters and two brothers along with our parents that night
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I then asked her,"How did we survive?"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: She told me that she wrapped me in a blanket, and ran away along with our brother Sunil
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: When they were running, Sunil had to go to the bathroom, and fainted
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The streets were so crowded
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: as people were running and shouting
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: my sister was forced by the crowd, and couldn't wait any longer for my brother Sunil to come back
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He succeeded in 2006
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when he hung himself
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: So, now it is just Mamta and I - the only survivors from a family of 10
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Mamta lives in Lucknow with her husband and two children
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I live here in Bhopal on my own
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: She would often complain about severe headaches and eye problems
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It has been almost 30 years now
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Bhopalis are still fighting for their basic rights
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The disaster took so many lives, and is still killing people, as the abandoned factory continues poisoning our soil, water, and air
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I started learning more about the disaster
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when I saw people of different ages chanting slogans in the streets of Bhopal when I was a child
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In 2004, Greenpeace flew me to Paris to participate in a demonstration outside Dow's shareholders meeting
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I got involved with the campaign in 2004 partly because of my brother's participation in the campaign
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was better to die fighting for our rights than succumb to depression over what had happened
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I had a stroke in 2005, and started taking an aspirin everyday
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I also had a pulmonary embolism in the US last year
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Now I no longer take an aspirin
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because now I have to take 7.5mg of warfarin, a blood thinner
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which is also used as rat poison
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In 2008, I was one of a number of Bhopal survivors in New Delhi who fasted for 21 days, only having water
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We were asking then Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to set up an empowered commission to look into the issues related to Bhopal
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We also wanted clean water to be supplied to the people who were living in the affected communities and were forced to drink contaminated water
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Everyone on this earth should feel this anger and frustration
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It has been 30 years and justice continues to elude the people of Bhopal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We, the people of Bhopal, believe that the whole world has transformed into a Bhopal in a way
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you look around
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: you see multinational corporations being allowed to do business without accountability, poisoning the world and placing profits over people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: justice comes to Bhopal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: then it would be justice for the whole world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It would set a precedent and ensure that in the future, corporations committing such crimes are brought to justice
paragraphs.label: assumption
